reviewText:
This shooter is more hits than misses with some nice boss battles and a narrative to add some character. However, it should be noted that the game is over in just over an hour with only 3 difficulty settings and leaderboards as an incentive to keep playing.

The game opens up with a brief introduction to its universe complete with a motive and an exaggerated do-gooder protagonist. Steam and Metal is not afraid to be silly (steampunk jokes and all) and its lofty writing is smirk inducing. The hand drawn slides area nice touch to give the game some character. The in game graphics and sound are pretty average, but the game certainly tries to leave an impression with its story.

The gameplay mechanics are standard but tight. You have a health bar and limited lives. Running out of lives will send you back to restart the level, however your score/pick ups will carry over to the next level so there is a strong incentive to stay alive. Pick ups include the usual suspects: health, extra missiles, extra lives, and bonus scores, but your firepower is based on picking up gears or bullets with each tier adding another stream of bullets. Some of the level designs are well made with death riddled mazes and telegraphed danger. The boss fights feel demanding at times and keep the player on their toes. However, this game will not appeal to everyone.

Compared to other shooters Steam and Metal felt a bit sluggish at times. The weapons are also very average: you fire a single stream of bullets at first, then as you collect gears you can add up to two more streams of bullets to total at three. Your missiles require you to hold down your button for a short amount of time before they can be released (they can be held while firing), which does force you to choose your targets carefully. Given the lack of weapon variety, and little strategy (in other games you have to juggle a shield or your speed increases when not firing, only one standard single player campaign etc.) this game is on the lighter side, especially when coupled with the brief campaign length.

Steam and Metal really is a score driven top down shooter. Your ship can take a limited number of hits (depending on difficulty), but you can receive a bonus for not being hit at all. Accuracy, enemies killed, missles used, etc. all factor into your final score. Given that there are only 6 levels and 3 difficulty levels, the realy meat of the game will probably come through multiple plays in order to carve your name on the leader boards.

Clocking in at a little more than an hour (with most of the achievements thrown in) this is a top down shoot 'em up that is overall enjoyable. This game is lacking in a few areas (like variety and depth), so those that are already knee deep in shoot 'em ups and bullet hells may want to look elsewhere for their fix. However this is a neat experience for those who are in the market for a streamlined and brief experience. This game boasts dynamic boss battles, solid game play, a short campaign, and a neat little narrative mixed in the middle of all the bullets, but I would recommend waiting for a sale/bundle.

reviewText:
ContextSteam and Metal is a shoot 'em up/bullet-hell game, set in a Steampunk universe, with a Grieg-inspired soundtrack!

This is a very good example of an amateur, yet very solid game! I was happy to play it, and it doesn't have too much that's wrong with it, which is surprising, as many people tend to ignore crucial details. This game does not.

However, it doesn't add anything to the genre, and while it's a solid game, it pains me how similar it is to Jamestown! Not just in setting and general vibe, but also in the way it fills the screen with little cogs, and some other details. In the credits, the developer says the game has been slowly baked" in 4 years

reviewText: Surprisingly interesting storyline -for a shump- with striking art style ala steampunk aestetic.  A great way to get some bullet-hell angst out against those evil corporate overlords plotting to use the steamengine for war instead of peace.  Happy to have supported this one through Greenlight via Lazy Guys.  This one is cool.

reviewText: Reminds me of a more colourful and humourous Battle Garegga (if they bring that to steam I'll shít myself). Definitely one to try out if you have fond memories of Mame emulated shmups of yore, especially with the worldwide leaderboard to show you how much you suck/rule compared to everyone else.

I had a hard time figuring out what direction to take this review in.

As a game, Steam & Metal is a typical, one might even say derivative bullet hell shooter, but as a larger whole I can’t quite decide where it falls on the line between shallow replication and intentional self parody.

Set in a 19th century world on the brink of a steam-powered renaissance, you take up the mantle of your late grandfather, genius inventor and creator of a machine of unstoppable power for which the blueprints have been stolen. All that was left behind is your flying machine and mechanically inclined mind, which are all that stands between you and the dastardly scoundrels who intend to turn your grandfather’s work against the world.

Its writing is so representative of a base starting point of steampunk as a genre that I wasn’t sure if I was intended to laugh at the cliche ridden dialogue and premise, or cringe at the excessively articulated speeches of its characters and their tendency to jump between societal commentary and poking fun at the meaninglessness of the plot they’d been stuck in.

But that in itself begins to disrupt the idea that Steam & Metal is anything but a poorly told retreading of every tired element of steampunk literature. Its attempts at self awareness only make it harder to swallow, pouring out line after line in such painful earnestly that I wanted to tell the game to stop shut up for its own sake.

But when it decides to stop talking its soulless gameplay left me lost as to even know where to begin to describe it. It’s a bullet hell shooter, only with few projectiles and more room to maneuver than usual. The screen quickly fills with the chaotic frenzy of your enemies, but it all feels pointless and existing without reason. There was no satisfaction in destroying enemy ships, no excitement from nimbly dodging through an onslaught of cannonfire, no pleasure to be found surpassing a difficult stage or defeating a tricky boss.

If I felt anything playing Steam & Metal it was that there was nothing especially wrong with the game, it just had nothing to offer me over almost any other bullet hell shooter out there. It’s a model of acceptable mediocrity; a project that seems proud of itself, but never find a way to project its enthusiasm outward. Instead it goes on, fully convinced it’s the coolest thing ever no matter how disinterested the player becomes. I guess that’s better than nothing.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText: Bought it for cards. Turns out it's really fun game. At least for a person who doesn't play SHMUPs that often. Gameplay is fluid and fun. Graphics are a bit meh, tho - at least the backgrounds :( Looks a bit like a Game Maker game from mid-2000's. Sometimes it's hard to tell what's in the background and what you will crash into.\n\n... and the god damn cards aren't apparently even added to the game yet..? :d

reviewText:
Generally a fun steampunk-themed vertical shmup, of a classic type rather than bullet hell. Features stage obstacles and a power-up system.

The graphics are generally pleasing, but not spectacular. Ditto for the music.

The game's biggest problem is the color palette of its shots. A number of enemy bullets — especially those shot by bosses — are grey cannonballs. This fits the aesthetic nicely, but it also has a tendency to blend into the background in a way that bullets in a shmup never should. In later boss fights this can become a major problem.

The lack of rebindable controls is also a major drawback, especially as the bomb-equivalent is bound the the decidedly nonstandard Ctrl key.
